key_insight: Represent long image sequences as a factorized grid of spatial tiles and model generation with a grid-based diffusion process, drastically reducing compute and memory compared to stacking full frames while preserving temporal continuity.
problem_solved: Addresses the inefficiency and scaling bottleneck of treating long image sequences as huge stacked tensors for generative modeling, which limits sequence length, increases compute/memory costs, and hampers practical long-sequence synthesis.
method: Factorize each frame into a grid of spatial tiles and treat the sequence as a structured collection of smaller units rather than a single large tensor.
Apply a diffusion-based generative model that operates over the grid factorization to model local spatial detail and cross-tile/temporal interactions efficiently.
Use hierarchical or factorized conditioning and sampling strategies to maintain temporal coherence while keeping training and inference complexity low.
impact: Enables scalable generation of much longer image sequences (e.g., long videos or animations) with lower computational and memory footprints, making advanced generative models more practical for research and deployment.

paper_title: GriDiT: Factorized Grid-Based Diffusion for Efficient Long Image Sequence Generation
paper_authors: Snehal Singh Tomar, Alexandros Graikos, Arjun Krishna, Dimitris Samaras, Klaus Mueller
